text: today we're tackling the Thanksgiving
conundrum roasting a turkey I'm going to
show you a really clever trick today on
how you can roast your Thanksgiving
turkey and have a wonderfully moist
breast meat and a thoroughly cooked dark
meat and the trick here is roasting the
turkey upside-down so to start instead
of putting a rack into the bottom of my
roasting pan here I'm going to use some
bread because the bread is really nice
and soft and it won't damage the breast
meat or the skin on top of the bird so
what I'm doing is I'm just leveling off
the top here so that I have a nice flat
piece of bread once I open this up and
this goes right into your roasting pan
so it sits nice and flat
now you're going to butter the bread of
course right and I'm using one stick of
unsalted butter here when you're
buttering the bread what you're doing is
you're making sure that the turkey skin
will not stick to the loaf of bread and
also what it will do is it will melt
down in the pan and give you wonderful
basting juices so that your turkey will
be beautiful and brown so now for the
turkey I have an 18 pound bird here and
this is a fresh turkey and what I'm
gonna do is I'm gonna season the bird up
with salt and pepper that's it now you
could use whatever spice blend you'd
like you could even stuff the turkey the
cooking times will change I'm going to
mix together let's see about a couple
tablespoons of salt and a couple
teaspoons of pepper and I look to this
in a separate Bowl because it keeps your
salt and pepper nice and clean liberally
sprinkle the inside and the outside of
the turkey it's very important to salt
the inside of the cavity of the bird
because flavor does penetrate in that
way as well
and I like to season before I tuck the
wings on Dirks I like to make sure that
the entire exterior of the bird is
coated now what I'm going to do is I'm
going to take the next skin and I'm
going to push it under the turkey
then what you're going to do is you're
going to take the wingtips and rotate
them underneath the breasts and this
helps to prevent the wingtips from
burning it also keeps a nice shape to
the bird and now for uniform cooking
it's always helpful to trust the bird so
I'm just going to take a small piece of
butchers twine and I'm going to tie the
legs together so now you're going to
take the bird and you're going to flip
it or invert it onto the top of the
bread just like that and it should sit
nicely in the center of the loaf with
the remaining salt and pepper just give
the underside which is now the top side
a liberal sprinkling of salt and pepper
so the great thing about this method
here is roasting upside-down the juices
kind of trickle down into the breast
meat and keep it nice and moist and the
dark meat which is on the top of the
bird now has direct contact with the
heat of the oven so it will cook at a
faster rate ultimately making the turkey
itself cook at an even rate and the
breast meat will be done at the same
time as the dark meat so into a
preheated 425 degree oven make sure that
the rack is set in the lower third of
the oven and you're going to put the
turkey in legs first because this will
help kick off that cooking so our Turkey
has been roasting at 425 degrees for
about 45 minutes now reduce the oven
temperature to 350 degrees and now is
the time to flip the turkey and you can
use a wooden spoon you can fit it into
the cavity here to help you leverage the
bird a little bit being very careful
flip the bird and you can see that the
breast here hasn't been damaged at all
there are no wire rack marks
so now let's goes back into your other
than 350 degrees and if you can fit it
into your oven with the neck end first
that would be great now if you can't fit
it in neck first you can do it from side
to side it's going to cook for about an
hour and a half in total and every 15 to
20 minutes you should baste it until
it's a nice golden brown color so it's
been about an hour and a half and our
turkey is out of the oven it's beautiful
it has a wonderful lacquered top from
all of the basting with the pan juices
now you want to make sure that when you
are roasting your turkey make sure that
you cook bite
temperature and not by cooking time or
by weight of the bird you want to insert
an instant-read thermometer into the
thickest part of the thigh avoiding bone
and that should register 165 degrees so
this needs to now rest before carving at
least 30 minutes so that the juices do
not run out you do not end up with a dry
bird but I do promise you that this
method of cooking a turkey upside down
will give you the most moist and
delicious and tender breast meat and a
wonderfully cooked dark meat and you
will be happy this Thanksgiving enjoy
